clinical_study.brief_title: Islet Function and Clinical Analyses of Transplant Recipients
clinical_study.official_title: Islet Function and Clinical Analyses if Transplant Recipients (Project 2 of JDFI Washington University Center For Islet Transplantation) (Please Note That the JDRFI Funded Has Ended

brief_summary.textblock: To follow the patterns and natural history of Islet Transplant recipients (the ones that were involved in the Modified Edmonton Protocol) using oral glucose to check sugar levels as well as insulin and C-peptide over the course of 5 years

primary_outcome.measure: OGTT will be performed every 6 months for 5 years in subjects with a functioning Islet Transplant

secondary_outcome.measure: The OGTT reflects the function of the Islet transplant and could be used as an indication of Islet Transplant function

arm_group.description: Subjects that have successfully received and maintained an Islet transplant at Washington University Center for Islet Transplantation
subjects that were similar in height, weight and age that did NOT have diabetes to act as the comparative group

intervention.description: Subjects would consume 75grams of sugar (Dextrose, 10 oz) and blood samples taken at specified time points to measure glucose, insulin and C-peptide

biospec_descr.textblock: Serum samples are obtained during the OGTT and stored in a -20degree freezer. They are tested for Insulin C-peptide and glucose.

study_pop.textblock: Type 1 diabetics that have successfully received and maintained an islet transplant here at Washington University. Loss of transplant function is an exclusion criteria.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Type 1 Diabetes with hypoglycemia unawareness that received a Islet Transplant here at Washington University
- "control" subjects were matched to the transplant recipients base upon age, height, weight, & race (and could not have diabetes)
Exclusion Criteria:
- well controlled Type 1 diabetes
- transplant failure
- unable to match potential subject to a recipient
